dialogue.text: If you go on from that point, I don't know where you go.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: 'Cause listen, I'm telling you, I don't know where to go from there. Do you?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, I don't know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What do you want from me?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Every time I reach out for something I have to pull back because other people will suffer. My whole entire life, time and time after time.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You're a considerate fella and there's nothing wrong in that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: To hell with that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: There's nothing wrong with it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I didn't ask Annie yet.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You didn't ask her yet?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I wanted to get this settled first.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, how do you know she's going to marry you? I mean, what if she feels the same way as your father?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well then I guess it's over then. But from her letters I think she's forgotten him.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'll find out. But then after it's all over we'll thrash it out with dad, right?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Mom, don't avoid me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You know, the trouble is you've never had enough women. No, you never did.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So what? I'm not fast with women.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't understand why it has to be her.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Because it is.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That's a good answer, but it doesn't answer anything.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I just-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I mean, you haven't seen her since the war. I mean, it's been five years.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It just is. I-

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I grew up with her. Okay. All these years, when I think of someone I want to be my wife I think of Annie. What do you want, a diagram?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, I don't want a diagram.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: He thinks he's coming back. You go-go on and marry her, I mean, you're pronouncing her dead. And what's going to happen to your father, huh? I don't know. Do you?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay. All right, then.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Just, listen. Give it more thought, is all.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, I've given it three years of thought.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And I thought that if I waited then dad would forget about Larry and then we could have a regular wedding and everything happy.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: But if I can't have that here then I'll get out.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What the hell is this?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'll get out. I'll marry her somewhere else. Maybe New York.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You're crazy.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I've been a sucker too long. I'm through with it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You're what-you're going to leave the business? But you can't do that. What the hell is this?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: The business. The business doesn't inspire me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, you have to be inspired.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes. I like it an hour out of the day. If I have to grub for money all day long at least that evening I want it beautiful. I want a wife. I want a family. I want some kids. I want to build something I can give myself to.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Now, Annie's in the middle of all that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Now, where do I find it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Tell me something.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You'd leave that business.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes. On this I would.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You can't do that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Then help me stay here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: All right, but you can't do that. You can't talk like that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay. Just-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: We've worked all our lives for you. Only for you, Chris. The whole shootin' match is for you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah, I know, I know, just help me stay here, all right?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm going to.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You just can't talk like that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I am thinking like that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't know you, do I?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, you don't. I'm a pretty tough guy.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah. I can see that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Can I help you sir?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes you can help me.  Where is my luggage?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, let me just check on that for you.  Where are you coming--?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.  You do that.  I'm coming from Baltimore.  You know where that is?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Sir, yes it's in Maryland.  It's okay...well, I'm...just let me check here.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I had eight hundred pounds of luggage.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Okay.  Sir?  Can you...if you just give me one moment and let me just check okay?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay.  Check.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Alright.  And you're coming-- Wait, hold on sir.  You're coming from Baltimore into LAX right?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Is it there?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Okay and this is direct flight?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You don't know where we're at?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: God.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm asking you if this is direct flight from Baltimore to LAX or if you have to stop--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know I've been waiting here for four hours for my luggage

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: and it's not here, they told me to go to this person, go to this person.  Now I'm at this person.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You're at me and I'm going to try to help you out sir but you just have to cooperate with me--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay.  What do you want?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How many pieces of luggage do you have checked in?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Eight.  And they're all gone.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Eight pieces of luggage.  Okay.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And what are you going to do about it?  You going to call someone?  You going to send me somewhere else?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.  I'm just going to check--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's my mother's funeral tomorrow and the urn is in the suitcase.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm sorry sir.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm very sorry but let's check on this immediately.  This is definitely an emergency.  It seems--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What am I going to do tomorrow without the urn?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Sir it seems to me that your luggage is um- is not here

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, oh, that's a good deduction.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yes--it is

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Sherlock Holmes.  God, where's my luggage?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Sir, Please please, I would ask you to just calm down for a second--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Calm down?  It's my mother's funeral tomorrow.  I'm the one responsible for this.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Okay.  We will find your luggage.  Apparently because it somehow...what flight you were taking, you were on Delta?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes.  You are a Delta representative.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yes, I am.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What is the matter with you?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Sir, I just...you need to calm down is what needs to happen right now.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Don't yell at me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Okay.  I'm not.  I'm sorry, I am being--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: calm.  Sir, okay basically what- what's going to happen here is you're going to give me your contact information and we will contact you--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh my God.  I think a blood vessel burst in my head.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Please, please

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: sir, listen to me.  Your luggage is still in Baltimore.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Okay.  We can get it here in about seven to ten business days.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What?  Are you kidding me?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yes.  Well, because--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Give- Give me your manager right now.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I am the manager sir.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You're the manager? You don't know where you work for, you don't know where you're at and you're the manager?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Sir I know where I work for but I was checking because you cannot--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Whose daughter are you?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Sir?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Sir. Sir. Sir. Sir

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What is your name?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: My name is Brent Caption.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Now what are you going to do about it?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That was a rouser, wasn't it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That was the first time you ever hit me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I didn't hit you very hard.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: The manager came in and found us rolling about on the floor, biting and scratching like panthers.  Oh, dear.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I shall never forget his face.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How ridiculous.  How utterly, utterly ridiculous.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We were very much younger then.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And very much sillier.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: As a matter of fact, the real cause of that row was Peter Burden.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You knew there was nothing in that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I knew nothing of the sort.  You took presents from him.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Presents?  A trivial little brooch.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I remember it well, bristling with diamonds in the worst possible taste.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Not at all.  It was very pretty.  I still have it and I wear it often.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You went out of your way to torture me over Peter Burden.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I did not.  You made the whole thing up in your jealous imagination.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You must admit that he was in love with you, wasn't he?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Just a little, perhaps, nothing serious.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Line?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Let him kiss you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You let him kiss you.  You said you did.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What of it?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What of it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It gave him a lot of pleasure and it didn't hurt me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What about me?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: If you hadn't been so nosey, you never would have known a thing about it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That's a nice point of view, I must say.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, dear.  I'm bored with this conversation.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So am I; bored stiff.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You want some brandy?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, thanks.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'll have a little myself, I think.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't see why you want it.  You've already had two glasses.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No particular reason.  Anyhow, they were very small ones.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It seems so silly to go on and on and on with such a thing.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You can hardly call three liquor glasses in a whole evening going on and on and on.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's become a habit with you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You needn't be so grand just because you don't happen to want any at the moment.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, don't be so stupid.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Really, Amanda

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Nothing.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Going out somewhere, my dear?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, just making myself fascinating for you

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh.  That reply has broken my heart.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: The woman's job is to allure the man.  Watch me a minute, will you?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: As a matter of fact, that's perfectly true.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, no, it isn't.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes, it is.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, be quiet.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Line?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's a pity you didn't- It's a pity you didn't have more brandy.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's a pity you didn't have any more brandy.  It might have made you a little less disagreeable.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It doesn't seem to have worked such wonders with you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Line?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Snap.  Oh, snap, snap, snap, like a little adder.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Adders don't snap, they sting.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: They -- nonsense, they have a little bag of venom behind their fangs and they snap.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: They sting.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: They snap.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't care.  Do you understand?  I don't care.  I don't mind if they bark and roll about like hoops.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Did you see much of Peter Burden after our divorce?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yes, I did, quite a lot.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I suppose you let him kiss you a good deal more then, hmm?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Mind your own business.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You must have had a riotous time.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No restraint at all, very enjoyable.  You never had much anyhow.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You're quite insufferable.  I expected it's because you're drunk.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm not in the least drunk.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You always had a weak head.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I think I mentioned once before that I've only had three minute liquor glasses of brandy this whole evening.  That's hardly enough to get a child of two drunk.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: On the contrary, a child of two could get violently drunk on only one glass of brandy.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Very interesting.  And how about a child of four and a child of six and a child of nine?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, shut up.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We might get up a splendid little- a splendid little debate about this, you know, intemperate tots.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Not very funny, dear.  You'd better have some more brandy.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Very good idea.  I will

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You better turn that off I think.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Why?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's late and the people upstairs will get annoyed.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: There aren't any people upstairs.  It's a photographer's studio.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: There are people downstairs, I suppose

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: They're away in Tunis.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: This is no time of year for Tunis.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Turn it on again, please.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I will do no such thing.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Very well, if you insist on being boorish and idiotic.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Turn it off.  It's driving me mad.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Go away.  Go away.  I hate you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Turn it off.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You are far too temperamental.  Try to control yourself.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: We swapped. Listen.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Listen--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Listen, indeed.  I am sick and tired of listening to you, you damn sadistic bully.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You're a vile tempered, loosed living

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Stop.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: wicked little beast. And I- I hope I never see you again as long as live.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Stop.  I hate you.  Do you hear me? You're conceited and overbearing and utterly impossible.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: This is the end.  Do you understand, the end?  Finally and forever.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You're not going like this.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, yes, I am.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, you're not.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Let go of me.  You're a cruel fiend and I hate and loath you.  Thank God, I discovered in time what you're really like.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Shut up. Shut up.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You're a mean, evil minded

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Marry you again? Huh.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: little vampire And I hope to God I never set eyes on you as long as I live.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Never, never, never.  I'd rather die in torment. Beast brute.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Whore.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Swine.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So you're leaving tomorrow.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah.  They just called.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: This is really-this is unfair.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I know.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't see [BREATHING]

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't know what to say.  I don't want to go but I don't have a lot of choice.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I mean we both knew that this was going to happen.  It's just that I feel that, you know, I don't want Susie growing up without a mother.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And, uh, I'm afraid that if you, you know, when you leave, you won't come back.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm going to come back.  I need you to believe that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You don't know that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I need you to believe that too.  How am I supposed to believe everything's going to be okay if you don't?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'll believe it, but- I'll believe it but it- I don't know that that's going to happen.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well you have to have faith because I don't have a choice and I have to go.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You do have a choice.  You don't have to go.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Do you think I want to leave you?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You have a choice.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I have to do this.  I don't want to leave.  Do you think I want to miss seeing her grow up?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know.  It's just you don't have to do this for a living you know.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You're a smart person.  There are other things you can do.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Look we both knew what this meant when I signed on

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And now- and now it's really shitty timing but now I have to go.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I mean I'm the one who has to leave here.  I'm the one who has to leave the two of you.  At least you get to be together.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's just not going to work out without you here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What's that supposed to mean?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I mean we can't-we're not a complete family without you here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well I'll come back.  What is that supposed to mean?  You're not willing to wait for me to come back?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Of course I'm going to wait.  I just- I just don't like the idea of this happening because this isn't the last time this is going to happen. You're going to go on more tours and stuff.  I just- I can't-

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I can't deal with this emotionally.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What do you want me to do?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I want you to leave.  I want you to leave the service.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well I can't very well do it today.  I still have to leave tomorrow.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You can do it today.  You don't have to do anything.  You don't have to do anything you don't want to do.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You're not making this any easier for me, you know.  I'm the one who has to go and you're really not helping.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Look I'm just telling you that you don't have to go.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I do have to go. And I need to know that you're here waiting for me and that you believe that I'm coming back.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That's all I'm saying... No you don't.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Thanks that helps.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's just really unfair.  This is- this is bullshit.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I feel much better now.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You're acting like, you know, you're the one who's going all through, you know, all this shit and it's really- it's really not.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I know I'm leaving you here with all the responsibility but at least you get to be with her.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.  Of course I do because I didn't enlist in this stupid thing.  Why don't you just get out now and then-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I will but I can't right now.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes- You don't have to go.  What are they going to do?  Huh?  Put a gun to your head?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You know- you know how this works.  I have to go.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Then go.  We'll be here when you get back.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That's how you want to leave it?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know how else to leave it.  What, do you want me to lie to you?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You want me tell you that I'm okay with it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I want you to be okay with it as much as you can be.  I mean it's not a great situation but we don't have an option here.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well I can't be okay with it the same way you can't not go.  It just doesn't work that way.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Fine.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Why did he invite her here?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, God, line.

dialogue.text: Oh Augie

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Did you ask Annie yet?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, I wanted to get this all sorted out first.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, how do you know she's going to marry you?  Maybe she feels same way your father does.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, if she does then that's the end of it.  However from her letters I think she's pretty much forgotten him.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: The trouble is you don't see enough women, you never did.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So what?  I'm just--I'm not fast with women.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't see why it has to be Annie.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Because it is.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That's a good answer but it doesn't answer anything.  You haven't seen her since you went away to war, it's been five years.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know, it I think of her, I grew up next to her.  She is what I think of when I think of a wife.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: He thinks he's coming back, Chris.  You marry that girl you're pronouncing him dead.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Do you know what that'll do to you, to your father, do you know?  I don't.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: All right then.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Give it some more thought.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I've given it lots of thought.  And I keep coming back to the same thing.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: When I think of a family, when I think of my future I see Annie in the center of that and you know and if that can't happen here then I'll go somewhere else.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What the hell is this?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'll leave.  I'll get married and move somewhere else maybe New York.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Are you crazy?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'll do it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You have a business here.  I said what the hell is this?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Business?  The business doesn't inspire me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, must you be inspired.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes, yes I like it for one hour a day.  I don't care if I have to grub for money all day long when I come home I want it nice, I want a family, I want to kids and Annie is in the center of that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: If that can't happen here...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You mean to tell me you would leave the business for this.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes, on this I would.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, you don't want to think like that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Then help me stay here mom.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: All right but you don't think like that because what the hell is this all for.  This is all for you, what are we working for Chris? The whole shooting match is for you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know, I know.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Then help me stay.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, you don't think like that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I am thinking like that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't understand you, do I?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, you don't.  I'm a pretty tough guy.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, I can see that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Next.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes, me. Okay, okay here we go.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: My window is open.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay, so filled out all these forms  --

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: This is... Your last- Your first name is Jones?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: and I have This form of ID here so...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes, Jones.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That's just strange I figured you filled in wrong sections.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What are you... what's...What are you applying for?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm just applying for another ID.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Another ID?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes.  I'm supposed to have three forms of ID for this.  It's a long story, I'm supposed to have three forms of ID for this other job I really don't get into but I need another...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Fine.  So I need ID.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I have it right here, yes.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, I need your ID to give you a second ID.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's really simple if you have a problem with it... Maybe you should--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: But that's...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That's why I'm here, that's why I was waiting in this line.  I need to get another form of ID.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, do you have your passport?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, I don't have a passport.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You have a birth certificate?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't where it is though, I don't have with me.  Can I get it from somewhere?  I mean...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What do you expect me to do?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I probably have to go wait another line to get my birth certificate don't I?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Probably.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You're very helpful.  What's your name?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Joy.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Hi, Joy.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Hi.   You know...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So can you help me or not?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I am..I don't..I don't understand what you want.  A driver's license or a California ID.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay. [BREATHING]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I need California ID.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Okay.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: On top of these other two forms of ID which I already have.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What... well, do you have a driver's license?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, I don't have driver's license.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Then how am I supposed to give you a California ID?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Did you even look at the form?  I filled it out all these questions--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Don't raise your voice with me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Did you even look at the form?  I've already answered these question.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Don't talk to me like I'm a child.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Do you know how long I've been working here? How long have you lived in California?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: If it makes you stop acting like a child.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I have been to California my whole--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Maybe you never been to the D.M.V. before, maybe you should get back in line.  You know what?  sit in line again and if you get my number ask for different one.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I am not...I'm not getting to back that line.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay, okay let's keep our voices down, okay?  I didn't come here to get in yelling match.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm perfectly calm.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I did not come in here to get in a yelling match with you, all right?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Uh huh.  I didn't come here get in yelling match either.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Just try and help me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: They don't pay me enough to deal people like you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: People like me, what is that supposed to mean?  You know, this is ridiculous.  Is there like a manager here, is there someone else that I can talk to?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Why?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: So you're not going to send me a thank you card, is that a problem? Is your are not going...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why, because I'm sick of talking to you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: 'Cause you're obviously not talking to me, you're just yelling at me, berating me and telling me I can't fill out forms right.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, dear. Oh, boo-foo-woo, foo-foo.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, no honey. And you're going to miss the Christmas card too. It's a shame. It's going to be a good, nice picture.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Sit back down.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Have you tried, uh, Craig's List?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Uh, what?  Craig's List?  Oh the internet thing?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't know.  Isn't that-- that's all like escort services and things like that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No.  There's regular jobs on there.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't know.  I mean I've been looking for so long that I just figured that--  I mean, I think things like Monster are a lot more reliable than just some random free board.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Uh huh.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm just saying I have a friend that got a good job on it so I was just recommending it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What kind of a job?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: He's like a manager for a theatre.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Really?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: He's like a house manager. Yeah.  It's a good job.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: He just...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: you know what?  I heard about that job.  I applied for that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You did?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah.  I saw a posting at the theatre.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: He got it?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You've been looking for a job for a long time; that was a long time ago.  Right?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Hmm.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What did he do?  What was so great?  I don't understand why they would pick him over me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know.  He had a really good resume I guess and--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: A resume?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.  Do you have a resume?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's kind of helpful when getting a job.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I just- I mean I call people up and I tell them what I'm good at.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well maybe we should sit down some time and you can just tell me all the stuff that you have done and I'll write it out.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't like- I don't like sending things in the mail.  I don't want my information out there.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No.  You can- or you can just bring it in person.  But they need, generally, something to see, you know, what kind of what that you've done, what kind of--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm there in front of them.  I'm telling them what I'm good at.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.  But the piece of paper helps, too.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Why?  It's a piece of paper.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No.  But it has an outline, you know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I just don't want this paper trail, you know.  I just don't want things following me around, like-.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know.  Okay.  Well, um. Maybe--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's just-- You know, I've had this problem before.  You're not the first person to tell me that I need a resume but...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay, yeah.  I would imagine.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: ..I just-..I just think it's kind of prejudiced and they are really discriminating against people who just aren't that way.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, sometimes you have to do things that you don't necessarily like to do to have a job. But the job affords you money, you won't have to be taking the bus right now.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That's baloney, that's baloney.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Please.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: maybe get a car.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I just, you know, think you should try a little harder maybe.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: you think that you're better than me because I don't have a car?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I didn't say that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You know, you're riding the bus, too.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I am riding the bus, but by choice.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Why?  What choice?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: To save the environment, carpool.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You're saving the environment. mmhmm

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes.  One less car at a time.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Interesting.  That's fantastic.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Mmhmm.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know, you don't have to take out your frustration on me, you know, just because...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm not frustrated.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: ...you can't get a job and refuse to have a resume.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Who do you think you are?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't think I'm anyone.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You are so high and mighty.  I just--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I- I-I didn't-- okay.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh.  I'm saving the environment. I'm riding this car because I- I want to.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What?  No.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What? Oh.  So now you're...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: The bus, I'm riding the bus because I want to.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: you know what?  You don't have to take your anger and your hurt out on me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I can not-- you are not here by choice.  Nobody would ride this bus by choice.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why not?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You're the only one who still loves his parents.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know.  It kind of went out of style, didn't it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's not so bad; it's a good thing.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [BREATHING] You know, it's lovely here.  The air is sweet.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You're not sorry you came.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm not sorry, no. But I'm...I can't stay.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why not?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: For one thing, your mother much as told me to go.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And then, you.  You've been kind of...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Sort of embarrassed ever since I got here.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well I was kind of planning of sneaking up on you over the course of a week or so.  They just take it for granted that we're all set.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I knew they would.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You did?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well sure, from your mother's point of view.  Why else would I come?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So would you want to?  I mean, I guess you have to know that's kind of why I asked you to come?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I, umm. I guess, I guess that's kind of why I came.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [BREATHING]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I love you. Annie, I love you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [LAUGHTER]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't really have any imagination, that's all I know how to say.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [LAUGHTER]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Am I embarrassing you? Are you - See, I didn't want to do it here with this yard, on this porch.  I wanted it to be somewhere new, some place fresh for both of us.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No. No

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You feel uncomfortable here, you feel that it's wrong here somehow.  I just...I don't...I didn't want...I didn't want to take you away from anything.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Chris, I've been ready a long, long, time.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And he's gone forever?  Are you sure?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I almost got married two years ago.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why didn't you?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You started to write me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You felt something that far back?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Every day since.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why didn't you let me know?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I was waiting for you, Chris.  You sure can be ambiguous, you know.  And when you did finally write me,

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Give me a...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Give me a kiss.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: God.  I kissed you Annie.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: beating around the bush.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I will never forgive you.  All I'd done was sit around wondering if I was crazy waiting so long, wondering if you were thinking about me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh Annie, we are going to live now.  I am going to make you so happy.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Not like that you're not.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I kissed you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Like Larry's brother.  Do it like you, Chris.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Chris, what is it?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Hey, let's drive some place.  Huh?  Let's get out of here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No. What is it?  Is it your mother?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No it's nothing like that. It's-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Then what?  Chris.  Even in your letters, there was something ashamed.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.  I suppose I have been. But it's going from me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You've got to tell me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't even know how to start.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It wouldn't work like this.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's just all mixed up with so many other things, you know?  You know overseas I was in command of a company?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah, sure.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well I lost them.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How many?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Pretty much all.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Aw, geez.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You can't just toss off a thing like that because they weren't just men. You know?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Like for instance, there was this one time it had been raining for several days and this kid he just came up to me and he gave me his last pair of dry socks.  He just put them in my pocket.  That's a little thing, you know, but that's what kind of guys I had.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: They didn't die, they killed themselves for each other.  I mean that, exactly.  Just a little more selfish and they would all be here today.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And I had this idea as I was watching them go down.  Everything was being destroyed, you know, but this one thing was being made.  It was kind of a monument, it's kind of responsibility, man for man.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Mmhmm.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: To bring that on to the earth again, you know, is like some kind of monument and I thought I would just make a difference to them.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: But then I came home and it was incredible, you know?  The whole thing was just kind of this random bus accident.  You know, I went back to the rat race again, I went to work.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Driving my new car and seeing a new refrigerator.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I mean...You can't take those things out of a war. when you drive that car and you see that new refrigerator, you have to know that it came out of the love that a man can have for another man.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And I didn't want any of it. I guess that included you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Do you still feel that way?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I just want you to know Annie.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Because you mustn't feel that way.  Everything you have, you've earned - everything.  you understand me?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Even me.  And your money?  Chris, there's nothing wrong in your money.  Your father put hundreds of planes into the air, you should be proud of that.  A man should be paid for that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Annie, Annie.  I am going to make a fortune for you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What would I do with a fortune?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Can I help you?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes, please help me.  Where is my bag?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I need a little more information.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Where is my bag?  Come on, I've been here for four hours.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What- What flight did you come in on?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay, I'm coming in from Atlanta.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Georgia?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes, Georgia.  Good for you I need my bag.  Can you...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: There's no need for you to raise your voice, sir.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I've been college educated.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I speak your language.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Are you insinuating that I don't have a college education and that- for some reason that makes you a better person than I am?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Listen, shut your smug mouth, okay?  I don't need that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm just saying you don't need to talk to me like I-

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I've been sitting here for four hours.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm not a child.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I've been here for sixteen.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You people have just been tossing me around like a used hanky.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I come here every single day.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You work here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Details, Details.  Well, anyhow can I--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: so you flew in from Atlanta...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: My bag from Atlanta.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Four...Four hours ago.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's a little black bag with wheels.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Do you have any i-?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That you wouldn't let me put in the overhead compartment.  You said I had to check it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I wouldn't let you?   I was not in Atlanta. I was not in Atlanta.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's a tiny little bag.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I had nothing to do with the boarding attendance.  I'm sorry that your seat was wherever it was.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, dear. Oh, boo-foo-woo, foo-foo.

dialogue.speaker: M

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Sit back down.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [BREATHING]

dialogue.text: [LAUGHTER]

dialogue.text: [LAUGHTER]

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No. No

dialogue.text: You felt something that far back?

dialogue.text: Give me a...

dialogue.text: God.  I kissed you Annie.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: beating around the bush.

dialogue.text: I will never forgive you.  All I'd done was sit around wondering if I was crazy waiting so long, wondering if you were thinking about me.

dialogue.text: Not like that you're not.

dialogue.text: No. What is it?  Is it your mother?

dialogue.text: Aw, geez.

dialogue.text: Mmhmm.

dialogue.text: I mean...You can't take those things out of a war. when you drive that car and you see that new refrigerator, you have to know that it came out of the love that a man can have for another man.

dialogue.text: And I didn't want any of it. I guess that included you.

dialogue.text: Do you still feel that way?

dialogue.text: I just want you to know Annie.

dialogue.text: Because you mustn't feel that way.  Everything you have, you've earned - everything.  you understand me?

dialogue.text: About what?

dialogue.text: About what I was saying.

dialogue.text: I think it's ridiculous.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: We just have different ideas of what this night is supposed to look like.

dialogue.speaker: M

dialogue.text: For God- Grow up, Augie.  The fish are not going to arrive.

dialogue.text: Why not?

dialogue.text: Because they never do.  Have they...Have they ever?

dialogue.text: We've missed them twice.

dialogue.text: Twice is every time we have tried; that's ever.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: They'll show up this time.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No they won't.  It's like waiting for Santa Claus.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I feel like my whole life is going to be spent standing on this beach with my eyes wide open and my hands clasped expectantly waiting for fish to show up.  And the fish never show up.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I thought you wanted to see it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You don't understand anything I am saying.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No. Of course not.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I did want to see it, I still do, I always do.  I just...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I feel like I'm always just standing here waiting.  I feel like this night is going to be the night, but it never is.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's just fish, it's nothing to get traumatized over.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: For God's sake, this is not about fish.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay.  I'm trying to work this backwards and pinpoint the exact moment where we took a turn for the worst here.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay.  So you were fine during that phone call from Marge and then dinner was okay.  And doing the dishes was fine and then I was going to take a shower and you're watching the news and you said the grunions are running tonight, do you want to go?  And I said, sure great, let's go.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay.  So I am putting out the pets, getting the car out of the garage.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Do you remember the first year we came here?  It was like four years after we got married.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: We thought I was pregnant, we got a bottle of champagne, we had no glasses.  We took off our shoes and you asked me to dance.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You whispered the sweetest, most intimate things to me right into my ear so I could feel them as much as hear them.  And I remember thinking, this is it.  You know, finally, I am as happy as I'm supposed to be.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Wait a minute, I got it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Drinking champagne from the bottle,

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's when we were driving past that Knickerbocker Liquor Locker, you said, let's get some champagne.  I said no, time's a wasting or something like that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: dancing barefoot in the sand.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That's what it is?  Right?  You want this to be like the other time, right?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'd rather not remember some things.  I'd rather not hope for some things.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Sure.  All right.  Okay.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Listen, do you want to dance?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Do you want me to go get some champagne?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Do you want to take off your shoes?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, no. Nothing.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Then what?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Do you want to get married again?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What?  What?  Do you want a divorce?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: A vacation?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Like a new carpet?  A poodle?  A back rub?  Ice cream?  A suicide pact?  What do you want?  What the hell do you want?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I just want something to turn out like I expected it to.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well welcome to the human race, huh?  Do you think I had some grand fantasy going that four years down the line we would come to this beach and be arguing over fish?  No.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [BREATHING]

dialogue.text: No I'm just like you.  I thought it was going to be all roses and peaches and the bills would just pay themselves.  And we'll have three, fat rosy cheeked children.  Huh, baby, the joke's on us.  Because you know what you get?

dialogue.text: Do you know what you get?  You get this.

dialogue.text: This? What is this?  This is nothing.  This isn't even anything.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes it is.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Sure.  This is standing on the beach waiting.  This is fighting.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Right

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I mean this is a lot of things, but it's just...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: [BREATHING]

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Do you understand what I am saying?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm doing the best I can.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I know you are Augie, I know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I know you meant this to be special, I know that you wanted it to be right, but I just can't help thinking that, I can't help wishing that I was somewhere else.

dialogue.text: Maybe if you were with someone else, too.

dialogue.text: I didn't say that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I just- I know I don't make you happy.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Don't be ridiculous.  Anything that- anything I am doing, I'd rather be doing it with you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah.  Don't you know that?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: For Heaven's sake Augie.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You're the one who probably wishes he was with somebody else.  Somebody who doesn't take things so seriously, who could enjoy herself.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know, actually now that you mention it, no I don't.

dialogue.speaker: F

dialogue.text: Hmm.  I noticed that, it's pretty. Big old white moon.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: [BREATHING]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And look what I got here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Augie, you bought refreshments.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's not champagne.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I guess we don't need glasses.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: [BREATHING]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Do you want to go home?  Are you cold?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm beginning to think this might be the right spot after all.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Augie, I'm sorry.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Shh.  If we're very quiet, the fish might come.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Or not.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Or not.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Check this out.  You know how I've told you I've been really into like softball recently?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, this is totally random, I got this full ride scholarship to go to U.S.C next year to play softball.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [LAUGHTER]. For softball? That's unbelievable. Is it slow pitch?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: For softball.  They're going to pay me to go to school. Isn't that awesome?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.  Well, I don't--well yeah I can pitch, I'm not like the pitcher though. I'm like the pinch hitter guy I mostly just hit.  But I guess I'm going to have to... Yeah, and then I play shortstop too but... It's so ex- The good news is I get to stay here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Uh huh.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Pinch hitting softball.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That is incredible.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That's amazing. They pay for everything?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know. For softball, yeah.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Your housing, books, everything? That is incredible.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah, everything. Every like- free ride and I get to, you know, like be on like a Trojans sports team too. And it's like cool. Isn't it awesome?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That is incredible. Do you get like a per diem?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know. I should ask. Yeah, I will.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You should...You should look into that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That is amazing, congratulations. Good for you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Thank you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: But I don't know I want to live in the housing that they give me though 'cause I think I want to you know like get like a nicer place.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah, that you probably. You should see one of these Victorian houses around by.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Where should I move?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That's a really good idea. Or I could go to like Santa Monica. Go beach. Venice beach, yeah a little dirty though. I don't want to go to Venice beach. But - Malibu. All right.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh. Venice beach.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, you don't like that. You're west-sider?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Okay. That would be way too much of a commute you can't do that. Especially- I know especially from--I don't know, what I was going to say, I don't know.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Professional softball player Malibu. [LAUGHTER]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: From where? Huh? Well I'm from San Francisco.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't know. Commuting from what Malibu that would be ridiculous.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh yeah, that would be.  Well, depends on what type of car you had, though too. I guess it would be worth it. helicopter. Yeah, helicopter.  There is a helipad there, right? Yeah, exactly.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh yeah. He'd drop you right off at practice?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Do you--are you one of those like four a clock in the morning practices?  Is it--that's more like swimming and- --ballet and things like that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah. I think it's in the afternoon 'cause I mean can't be too early 'cause then you can't see the ball.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: They have those neon--softballs.  They're like day-glow you can see them anywhere.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah, but no. Well, they have a night games but you know there's more like night games they're not like morning games, you know. I guess it's kind of same thing.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm surprised you don't know that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh. That is incredible. Is it--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: do they have a--is it a co-ed softball team?  I mean... Really? You know, I didn't even know that they have that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No it's all boys. All boys' softball team.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: They do it's--believe me it's huge.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Who do you play? Like do--are you like... nationally ranked?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I just got into it. I just kind of fell into it. Literally I was walking around and...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That is unbelievable.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's pretty wild.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I would put that right up there with--ping-pong.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah, well I doubt [GARBAGE] ping pong [GARBAGE]

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I mean not to denigrate what you are doing.  I think that's great.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh you mean it's not really sport that what you're saying?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, no.  I love softball. I played softball all the time.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's totally a sport. What are you talking about?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What, just 'cause I don't play regular baseball doesn't mean I'm like any less of like a sports guy.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I am not saying you should be. I'm not no. I think it's great I think you should be incredibly proud yourself especially because you're going to U.S.C for free for doing it. For free.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: For free that's really what it's about. I mean who cares I mean if I have to play softball all the time?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: But they got to like drive around in a bus--that would suck.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh really? With the whole team?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah we have like away games and stuff.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What are your teammates like? I'm sure you don't know yet? What kind of people play softball?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: They're nice.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Like, you know like police officers, like--kind of heavyset guys. Mustaches, yeah. It's that kind of-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh really?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Cool. You don't seem like you'd fit in there.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That kind of...They're okay.  No I'm like- I'm kind of like the odd man out I'm like...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, cool.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: But you know I'm like [GARBAGE].

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You're like the rookie? The new kid.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Just watch in five years you'll be like on the force. You carry around donuts in your back pocket... [LAUGHTER]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm going to have a mustache...On the force...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Pull over..

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What's he going to say?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Maybe we should tell him before he sees it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: He saw it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How could he see it?  I was the first one up; he was still in bed.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: He was out here when it broke.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: When?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Four o clock this morning.  I heard a crack and I woke up and looked out.  He was standing right over there when it cracked.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What was he doing out here at four o clock in the morning?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: He's dreaming of him again, walking around.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I guess he is.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's getting to be just like after he died.  What's the meaning of that?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know the meaning of it.  But I know one thing, Mom, you've made a terrible mistake with father.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Being dishonest with him, you know.  This kind of thing always pays off and it's paying off.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What do you mean dishonest?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know Larry is not coming back and I know it.  Why do we allow him to go on thinking that we believe with him?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What do you want to do?  Argue with him?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't want to argue but it's time he realized that nobody believes Larry is alive.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know?  Why shouldn't he walk the nights thinking of him, dreaming of him?   Do we contradict him?  Do we say, we don't have any hope anymore?  That we haven't had any hope for years now?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You can't say that to him.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We've got to say it to him.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Where's the proof?  Do you have any proof?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: For God's sake, three years?  Nobody comes back after three years; that's insane.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: To you it is, to me it is, but to your father, you can talk yourself until you are blue in the face.  But there is no grave and there is no body, so where are you?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Sit down, Mom.  I want to talk to you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's that the trouble is those God damn newspapers.  Every month some new boy comes back and so the next one is going to be Larry, they just--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: All right, all right, all right.  You know why I asked Annie here, right?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Why?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well I got an idea, but what's your story?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm going to ask her to marry me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well that's only your business, Chris.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know it's not just my business.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well what do you want me to do?  You're old enough to know your own mind.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So all right then, I'll just go ahead with it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well you want to make sure that your father is not going to --

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Then it's not just my business.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm just saying.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know sometimes you infuriate me.  you know that?  Isn't it your business if I tell father and he throws a fit about it?  God, you have such a talent for ignoring things.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh.  I ignore what I got to ignore.  That girl is Larry's girl.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: She's not Larry's girl.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: From your father's point of view, he is not dead and- Chris he still thinks he's still alive.  The girl is Larry's girl.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Now you can go on from there if you know where to go, but I'm telling you, I don't know where to go.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know why it is, but every time I reach out for something I have to pull back because I am afraid other people will suffer. My whole bloody life, time after time.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You're a considerate fellow, there's nothing wrong in that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: To hell with that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I just don't see why.  Have you asked Annie yet?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I wanted to get this settled first.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well how do you know she's going to marry you?  Maybe she feels the same way your father does.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well if she does, then that's it.  That's the end of it.  From her letters, though, I think she's pretty much forgotten him.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And then we'll thrash it out with father.  Okay Mom?  Don't avoid me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: The trouble is you don't see enough women.  You never did.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So what.  I'm not fast with women.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Why does it have to be Annie?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Because it is.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh that's a great reason.  It's no reason at all.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You haven't seen her since you went away to war, it's been five years.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I can't help it, I know her best.  I was brought up next door to her, you know?  These years when I think of someone for my wife, I think of Annie.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Mom, what do you want?  A diagram?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't want a diagram.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: He thinks he's coming back Chris.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You marry that girl, you are pronouncing him dead...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: ...and then what's that going to do to your father?  Do you know?  I don't.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: All right, then, Mom. [BREATHING]

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Just give it some more thought.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I've given it three years of thought.  And I'd hope that if I waited, father would forget about Larry and then we could just have a regular wedding and everyone would be happy.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: But if I can't do that here, I may have to go somewhere else.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What the hell is this?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'll get out.  I'll get married and I'll move somewhere else, maybe New York.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Are you crazy?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I've been a good son for too long, a good sucker.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You have a business here.  What the hell is this?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: The business?  The business doesn't inspire me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh.  Must you be inspired?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes.  I like it for an hour a day.  I don't care if I have to grub for money all day long, when I come home I want it happy.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I want some kids, I want a family, I want somebody that I can give myself to and Annie is in the center of that.  Now it's just where to find it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You mean to tell me that you would leave the business over this?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: On this, I would.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well you don't want to think like that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Then help me stay here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: All right.  But you don't want to think like that because what the hell are we working for, Chris?  It's all for you.  This whole shooting match is for you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know that.  Then just help me stay here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Just don't think like that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well I am thinking like that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't understand you, do I?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No.  You don't.  I'm a pretty tough guy.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I can see that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Good God.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Is it them?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I wonder.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Freda is the only one who knows we are here.  She wouldn't ring up.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It must be them then.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It had to happen sooner or later.  What are we going to do?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: [BREATHING]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We are okay, aren't we darling?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Now and always, sweet.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't care then.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It had to happen sooner or later.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Hello?  Hello?  I'm sorry, what's that?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No.  Wrong number. [LAUGHTER]

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [LAUGHTER] That sent shivers up my spine.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What shall we do if they suddenly walk in on us.[LAUGHTER]

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: We'll behave exquisitely.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: With perfect poise.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I think I shall do a curtsy.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's strange; things that ought to matter dreadfully, they just don't matter at all when one's happy.  Do they?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Hmm.  The pity is that one can't stay happy.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Darling, don't say that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's true.  I think the whole thing's a cruel joke.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What?  This beautiful and sacred thing - love?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yes.  Meaning just that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well what does it all mean?  That's what I ask myself in my quest for ultimate truth.  Dear God, what does it all mean?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Don't laugh at me.  I'm being serious.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh darling, you mustn't be serious.  It's just what they want.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Who's they?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: All of those futile moralists who make life unbearable.  You have to laugh at them, be flippant.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know, flippancy brings out the acid in their darned, light and sweetness.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: you know if I laugh at everything then I must laugh at us, too.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh of course.  We are figures of fun.  All right.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How long with it last, this ludicrous overbearing love of ours?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Who knows?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Shall we always want to bicker and fight?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh no.  That fire will fade along with our passion.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh dear, should we like that?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well it depends on how well we've played.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What happens if one of us dies?  Does the other one still laugh?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes.  Yes with all of his might.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well that's serious enough, isn't it?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, no, no, no. no.  Death is a very laughable thing.  It's a cunning little mystery, it's all done with mirrors.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I think you are talking nonsense.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh.  So is everyone, in the long run.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Let's be superficial, and just pity those poor philosophers, huh?  Let's blow trumpets and squeakers and enjoy the party for as long as we can, you know, like small, idiotic school children.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [LAUGHTER]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh Come and kiss me darling before your body rots and worms pop out of your eye sockets.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh Elliott, worms don't pop.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh See, I don't care what you do, see.  You can paint yourself green and run naked through the Place Vendome and run off with all of the men of the world.  I shan't say a word, just as long as you love me best.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Aw.  Thank you, darling.  The same applies to you too, except that if you so much as look at another woman I'll kill you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Do you remember that awful scene we had in Venice?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Which particular one?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: The one where you put that tiny painted wooden snake in my bed.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh Charles, that was his name.  He did wiggle so beautifully.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: [GARBAGE]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It was a terrible thing.  I hated it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I know you did.  You threw him out the window into the Grand Canal.  I'll never forgive you for that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: How long did that row last?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It went on intermittently for days.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Uh huh.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: But the worst one was in Cannes when your curling irons burnt a hole in my new dressing gown.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh And it burnt my comb, too, and all of those towels in the bathroom.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That was a rouser, wasn't it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [LAUGHTER] That was the first time you hit me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I did not hit you very hard.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: The manager came in, he found us rolling about the floor, biting and scratching like panthers. [LAUGHTER]  How utterly, utterly ridiculous.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: [LAUGHTER] I'll never forget his face. [LAUGHTER]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: [LAUGHTER] We were very much younger then.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [LAUGHTER] And very much sillier.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: However I believe the real cause of that row was Peter Burden.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh.  You knew there was nothing in that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What time is it?  God, this is great, isn't it?  I can't believe it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Of course I did want to a little further up the coast you know get away from all the lights and people and everything.  Is it midnight, do they always start at midnight?  Is that what it is midnight?  How you doing, huh? You okay?  That's good.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm fine.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Look, there what's that, what's that?  Is it--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, I think that's just foam.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Ugh...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, no I can't tell though.  Although probably if you can't tell it probably isn't them right, yeah.  Probably going to be like unmistakable, right?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Gosh, this is great, isn't it?  This is awesome.  Oh, no you know what I forgot?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: My flashlight.  How could I forget my flashlight?  God--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What flashlight?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Flashlight the silver one.  There's only one isn't there?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That's not your flashlight.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Whose is it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's ours; it's my flashlight, too.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, well, yeah of course.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You keep saying "my flashlight" like somehow it's just yours. How's that supposed to make me feel?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Of course, our flashlight.  What's your is mine, mi flashlight es su flashlight.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Gosh, I should have brought it. I can't believe I forgot that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's a nice moon though, should stay full.  Do they always run during a full moon?  I can't remember was it full last year?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: M

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [BREATHING]

dialogue.text: [LAUGHTER]

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [LAUGHTER]
