dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No. No

dialogue.speaker: M

dialogue.text: You started to write me.

dialogue.text: You felt something that far back?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Every day since.

dialogue.speaker: M

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I was waiting for you, Chris.  You sure can be ambiguous, you know.  And when you did finally write me,

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Give me a...

dialogue.text: Give me a kiss.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: God.  I kissed you Annie.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: beating around the bush.

dialogue.text: I will never forgive you.  All I'd done was sit around wondering if I was crazy waiting so long, wondering if you were thinking about me.

dialogue.speaker: M

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Not like that you're not.

dialogue.text: I kissed you.

dialogue.speaker: F

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No. What is it?  Is it your mother?

dialogue.text: No it's nothing like that. It's-

dialogue.text: I don't even know how to start.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It wouldn't work like this.

dialogue.text: Yeah, sure.

dialogue.text: Aw, geez.

dialogue.text: Like for instance, there was this one time it had been raining for several days and this kid he just came up to me and he gave me his last pair of dry socks.  He just put them in my pocket.  That's a little thing, you know, but that's what kind of guys I had.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: They didn't die, they killed themselves for each other.  I mean that, exactly.  Just a little more selfish and they would all be here today.

dialogue.speaker: M

dialogue.text: Mmhmm.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: To bring that on to the earth again, you know, is like some kind of monument and I thought I would just make a difference to them.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Driving my new car and seeing a new refrigerator.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I mean...You can't take those things out of a war. when you drive that car and you see that new refrigerator, you have to know that it came out of the love that a man can have for another man.

dialogue.text: And I didn't want any of it. I guess that included you.

dialogue.text: Do you still feel that way?

dialogue.text: I just want you to know Annie.

dialogue.text: That's out of control.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Fine.

dialogue.text: That's not your flashlight.

dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.text: How's that supposed to make me feel?

dialogue.speaker: M

dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.text: [LAUGHTER]

dialogue.text: I'm cold.

dialogue.text: Yeah they do.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh Augie

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm just not.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: For real?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: God, I don't get it.  you know the first time we came here, you said it was the best night of your life?

dialogue.text: And last year, I remember distinctly you said, you were so excited to get here that you don't remember you stubbed your toe until we were in the car.

dialogue.text: Ahh...we weren't in a good spot.

dialogue.text: Hmm.  We didn't see them the year before either.

dialogue.text: We just weren't in a good spot.  I'm telling you, this is a much better spot.  I have instincts for these things.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Look there, see?  What's that?  No, that's - that's just seaweed.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: God, this is great.  Think about this.  I know you are not interested, but just think about this.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Right now out there, there is this mass of silver fish and it's heading this way.  No one sent them an invitation, no one told them, no one even gave them a map.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Just all at once, they turned and they formed this line as long as the California coast.  And some instinctual little firecracker went off in their bodies and they all just turned as one and started swimming.

dialogue.text: They are swimming right now.  They are swimming as if that is the only thing that matters to them.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's single mindedness with no mind.  It is urgency that is just pure urge.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And they are swimming right now to this very point where we stand for this huge celebration of sex and death.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh look.  I'm giving myself goose bumps, my hairs are standing up on my arm.

dialogue.text: That's the wind.

dialogue.text: So what do you think?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: About what?

dialogue.text: Did you get the letter?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah. That is so awesome.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh my God. What are you going to do? [LAUGHTER]

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: So I have to move back to the ghetto but...I know.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh-Yeah, I bet you're really excited. Oh.  That's what loans are for?  Right? Exactly.

dialogue.text: I'm really excited.  Yeah. I don't know how I'm going to pay for anything, but... I also- Yeah.  Loans, too, yeah. I applied, though, for a bunch of grants and scholarships so I'm still waiting to hear on that.

dialogue.text: Oh.  Good, good.  That's awesome. Are you going to stay around here?  Or are you going to like get a different neighborhood- you going to move to a different neighborhood?

dialogue.text: Oh- I know, I know, I know, I know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't know.  I spend so much time commuting as it is, I'd rather.

dialogue.text: This is so- I am so happy that you're going to stay.  You're not going to...We should totally throw a party.

dialogue.text: I know. We should throw a party.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: At Arapaho we could afford that. [GARBAGE]. Yeah.  So what are you doing this summer, though?  You're staying around, too, yeah?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: A rapper party ho. Yeah. Okay.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I am just- Yeah.  I'm sticking around, I'm just doing my thing.  I'm living here.  I'm so glad you're going to stay, I'm so glad you're going to be here. Yeah. Woo.

dialogue.text: Oh, okay.

dialogue.text: Ooh. Fancy.

dialogue.text: Yeah.  I'm not sure.

dialogue.text: Yeah, I suppose I have been.  But it's going from me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You've gotta tell me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know how to start.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It wouldn't work this way.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's all mixed up with so many other things.  You remember overseas, I was in command of a company?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah, sure.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, I lost them.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How many?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Just about all.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, gee.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It takes some time for a guy to toss that off.  'Cause they weren't just men.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: For instance, one time, it had been raining several days and this kid came to me and gave me his last pair of dry socks.  I put them in pocket.  It's only a little thing, but that's the kind of guys I had.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: They didn't die, they killed themselves for each other.  I mean that exactly.  A little more selfish and they'd have been here today.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I got this idea watching them go down.  Everything was being destroyed, see, but it seemed that there was one new thing being made.  A sort of responsibility.  Man for man.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know what I mean?  To show that, to bring that onto the Earth again, like some kind of monument and everyone would feel it standing behind him and it would make a difference to him.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Then I came back and it was incredible.  There was no meaning in it here.  The whole thing to them seemed like sort of a bus accident.  I went to work with Dad and that rat race again.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And I felt what you said, ashamed somehow 'cause nobody was changed at all.  It seemed to make suckers out of a lot of guys.  I felt wrong to be alive to open the new bank book, drive the new car, see the new refrigerator.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I mean, you can take those things out of a war, but when you drive that car, you've gotta know that it came out of the love a man can have for a man.  You've gotta be a little better because of it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Because otherwise all you have is really loot and there's blood on it.  And I didn't want to take any of it.  And I guess that included you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You still feel that way?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I want you now Annie.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: 'Cause you mustn't feel that way.  Because you have a right to everything that you have.  Do you understand that?  Everything, Chris, and me too.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I mean, and your money, there's nothing wrong with your money.  I mean, your father put hundreds of planes in the air.  A man should be paid for that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know Annie.  Annie, I'm gonna make a fortune for you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What'll I do with a fortune?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: As a matter of fact, the real cause of that row was Peter Burden.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Honey, you knew there was nothing in that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I knew nothing of the sort.  You took presents from him.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Presents?  Just a trivial little broach.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Ah, yes, I remember it well.  Bristling with diamonds in the worst possible taste.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, it wasn't.  It was very pretty.  I still have it and I wear it often.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You went out of your way to torture me over Peter Burden.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, I didn't.  You worked the whole thing up in your jealous imagination.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You must admit, he was in love with you, wasn't he?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Just a little perhaps, nothing serious.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You let him kiss you.  You said you did.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, what of it?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What of it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It didn't hurt him at all and I enjoyed it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, what about me?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, if you hadn't been so suspicious and nosey, you never would have known a thing about it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, that's a nice point of view I must say.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm bored with this conversation.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Me, too.  Bored stiff.  You want some brandy?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, thanks.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I think I'll have some.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Don't see why you want any.  You've already had two glasses.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No particular reason.  Anyhow they were very small ones.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Just seems so silly to go on and on and on with such a thing.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You can hardly call three liquor glasses in a whole evening going on and on and on.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, it's become a habit with you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You needn't be so grand, just because you don't happen to want any yourself at the moment.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Don't be so stupid.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Really, Amanda.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Nothing.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Going out somewhere dear?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, just making myself fascinating for you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That reply has broken my heart.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: A woman's job is to allure the man.  Watch me a minute, will you?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: As a matter of fact, that's perfectly true.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, it isn't.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes, it is.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, be quiet.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Ah, it's a pity you didn't have any more brandy.  It might have made you a little less disagreeable.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Doesn't seem to have worked such wonders with you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Snap, snap, snap, like a little adder.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Adders don't snap, they sting.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Nonsense.  They have a little bag of venom behind their fangs and they snap.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: They sting.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: They snap.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't care, do you understand?  I don't care.  I don't care if they bark or roll about like hoops.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Did you see much of Peter Burden after our divorce?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yes, I did.  Quite a lot.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Hmm, I imagine you let him kiss you a good deal more then.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Mind your own business.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, must have had a riotous time. No restraint at all.  Very enjoyable and never had much anyhow.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You're quite insufferable

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I expect it's because you're drunk.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm not in the least drunk.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You've always had a weak head.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: As I mentioned before, I have had three minute liquor glasses of brandy the whole evening long.  A child of two couldn't get drunk on that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: On the contrary, a child of two could get violently drunk on only one glass of brandy.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, very interesting.  How about a child of four?  A child of six?  Or a child of nine?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Shut up.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We could get a good debate going about this, don't you think?  Intemperate tots.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Not very funny, dear.  You'd better have some more brandy.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: All right.  I will.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You better turn that off, I think.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Why?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Because it's late and it'll annoy the people upstairs.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: There aren't any people upstairs.  It's a photographer's studio.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: There are people downstairs I suppose?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: They're away in Tunis.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: This is no time of the year for Tunis.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Turn it on again, please.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'll do no such thing.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Very well, if you insist on being boorish and idiotic.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Turn it off.  It's driving me mad.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You are far too temperamental.  Try to control yourself.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Turn it off.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Stop it.  Go away.  I hate you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Amanda, listen. listen

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Listen?  Listen, indeed.  I am sick and tired of listening to you, damn sadistic bully.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Very amusing, indeed.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I hate you.  Stop it.  Stop it.  I hate you, do you hear?  You're conceited and overbearing and utterly impossible.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You're a vile, tempered, loose living, wicked little beast and I hope to never see you again as long as I live.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: This is the end.  Finally and forever.  Do you hear me?  The end.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You're not going like this.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh Yes, I am.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You're not.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I am.  Let go of me.  You're a cruel fiend and I hate and loathe you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Shut up. Shut up.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I wouldn't-- I wouldn't marry--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I wouldn't marry you if you came in crawling on your knees

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Thank God I realized what you are-- I'd never marry you again ever in my life. You're a cruel fiend and I hate you. You're a beast. You're a beast--I hate you. Stop it.  Stop it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You're a evil vampire and I hope to God I never see you again as long as I live.

dialogue.text: So, how's it going?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's going really well.  Um, I received something in the mail today.

dialogue.text: Oh, no way.

dialogue.text: Yeah, I'm so excited.  So I'm gonna say--

dialogue.text: Are you gonna go? you gonna-

dialogue.text: Yeah, I think, I mean because where else would I gonna go?  Like the other places that I applied to I really didn't like that much anyway.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: So--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Wow, that's...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: ...that's first choice, huh? That's so awesome and now look you're gonna be--you're gonna be here. you know

dialogue.text: Yeah, I know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Absolutely. I'm so excited.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I know.  I know. And we'll all get to hang out.  And I'm--even though we'll be at like at different parts of the city, we can still, like...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: ...hang out and, like, have our different lives--And meet each other's friends and stuff.  So, I'm just so glad 'cause they have such a good school

dialogue.text: Yeah, no, definitely--It's gonna..

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah

dialogue.text: Fight on.

dialogue.speaker: F

dialogue.text: [LAUGHTER]

dialogue.text: Wow. That's cool.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: ...like, they feel like--I feel like it's going to be so like accomplished.  Do you know what I mean?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Like it has some prestige. so

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah. Hey. Prestigious school.

dialogue.text: So, what, do you have to send in your deposit now?  Or what you-?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah, I mean there's all the money stuff and my mom's helping me with the financial aid and stuff.  But, it'll be fine--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Like, now that I'm accepted, it's just, like, such a huge load off my mind.

dialogue.text: That's great.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't mind worrying about all the paperwork.  You know--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.text: So...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Right.  Right.  Right. Oh, man, then you're going to have to do orientation, I guess.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I know. I know.  I think you go and you like stay for a couple of days and you meet people and--And they'll give you like a tour--And show you everything.  Oh, man, I'm just so--I'm so excited.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That'll be awesome.

dialogue.speaker: M

dialogue.speaker: F

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You know what I mean?  Like, it's like exactly what I want.

dialogue.text: Oh man.

dialogue.text: I know, I get to be one of those now--I'll like walk around and be like a U.S.C..  You know what I mean.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know is like.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Ahh. Yeah. [GARBAGE]

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And you'll be like...

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Student. I'm a student. Yes I am, Thank you very much.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [BREATHING]

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I know.  I'm excited.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, that'll take a while. [GARBAGE]

dialogue.text: I know, that's a ways down the road. That's cool.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That's going to be a lot of work.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: But, it'll be fine, I mean.  I'm so excited. It's going to be so fun.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: In LA. Oh man.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I know, and I mean the area's not great, but like the school makes up for it. It'll be fine. It'll be good.

dialogue.text: So much.

dialogue.text: But it's LA, you know, everything.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You're getting close to the beach.  I mean geez.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I know. I know. So fun.  I can't wait.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Cool.  Well give me a call, you know when--You get in town. definitely Awesome.

dialogue.text: I will. I will. Thank you.

dialogue.text: Thanks.

dialogue.text: Well

dialogue.text: Okay, so what are you saying? What-

dialogue.text: Well, I'm sorry sir but

dialogue.speaker: M

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, it's actually-

dialogue.text: Okay. What about - no -- how about you hold that and I'll - I'll go and I can come back-

dialogue.text: I'm sorry, but there is a lot of people waiting so you're just going to have to get in line again.

dialogue.text: I've been waiting for three hours.

dialogue.text: This is ridiculous. Come on

dialogue.speaker: M

dialogue.text: there is nothing I can do.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm sorry, sir. There is nothing I can do.

dialogue.text: Well, maybe you should

dialogue.text: God, oh my-

dialogue.text: This is ridiculous.

dialogue.text: Well-

dialogue.text: Oh, Annie.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: from her opinion, why else would I come here?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Annie, I love you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I love you a great deal.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I-I love you. I have no imagination. That's all I know how to tell it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, I guess that's why I came.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm embarrassing you. I didn't want to tell you it here. I wanted to go somewhere that would be brand-new to each other. It feels wrong here, don't you? This yard and this chair.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't want to win you from anybody. I want you to be ready for me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I've been ready for a long, long time.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Then he's gone forever. You're sure?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Look

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I was almost married two years ago.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why didn't you?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: 'Cause you started to write me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You felt something that far back?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Every day since.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why didn't you let me know?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, I don't know, you didn't write until then and then when you did, what'd you say?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You always can be so ambiguous.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Give me a kiss, Annie.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Give me-

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: [LAUGHTER]. God, I kissed Annie. I kissed Annie. How long, how long I've been waiting to kiss you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't know if I ever can forgive you for that. Why'd you wait so long? I sat in my room wondering if I was crazy for thinking about you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We're going to live now. I'm going to make you so happy.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Not like that, you're not.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I kissed you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Like Larry's brother. Do it like you, Chris.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What is it?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Let's drive somewhere. I want to be alone with you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No. What is it? Is it your mother?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, no, no, no. Nothing like that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well then tell me what's wrong. I mean, even in your letters there's something ashamed.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah. I guess there is. I guess I was, but uh- it's going from me now.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You should tell me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know where to start.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: But, Chris, it wouldn't work like this.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know when I went overseas. I said I was in command of a company.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah, sure.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, I lost them.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How many?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Just about all.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Geez.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It takes a little while to toss that off. Because they weren't just men.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: For instance, one time, it had to have been raining several days. There was this one kid, he came up to me and he gave me his last pair of dry socks. Put them in my pocket.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I mean, that's-that's only a little thing, but that's the kind of guys I had. They didn't just die. They killed themselves for each other. And I mean that exactly. A little more selfish and they'd still be here today.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And I, and I thought something watching them go down.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Everything was being destroyed, see, but there was one new thing that was being created. A kind of responsibility, man for man. You understand me?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And to show that-to bring that onto the earth like some sort of monument standing right behind us where everyone could feel it and it would make a difference to him.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And I came back here and it was incredible. There was no meaning in that here. The whole thing to them was a bus accident.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And I went to work with dad and that rat race again. And I felt what you said-ashamed somehow. Because nobody was changed at all. It seemed to make a sucker out of a lot of guys.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And I felt wrong to be alive. To drive the car, to see the new checkbook, to see the new refrigerator. I mean, you can take those things out of the war. But you got to know that when you drive that car that that came out of the love a man can have for another man. And you got to be a little bit better because of that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Otherwise, what you have here is loot; and there's blood on it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And I didn't want to take any of it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And I guess that included you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And you still feel that way?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I want you now, Annie.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Because you can't feel that way, never again, Chris. You hear me? Never. I mean, the money and me too.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I mean, there's nothing wrong in that money, and your father put good planes up in the air and you should be proud of that. A man should be paid for that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Annie,

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Annie, I'm going to make a fortune for you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What am I going to do with a fortune?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Why did you invite her here?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why? Does that bother you?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: She's been in New York for three-and-a-half years. She don't just suddenly come and-

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, maybe, maybe he just wanted to see her.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You don't travel seven hundred miles just to see.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What do you mean? They lived next door to each other their entire lives. Why shouldn't he want to see her? Hey, don't look at me like that. I don't know anymore than you do.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: He's not going to marry her.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: How do you know he's even thinking about it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's got that about it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, so what?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What's going on here, Joe?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Listen, kid-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: She's not Larry's girl. She knows that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You can't read her mind.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Then why is she married? Then why isn't she married? She's been in New York and there's hundreds of single men there.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm sure hundreds of them asked her and told her that she's foolish, but no.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: She's waited.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: How do you know why she's waited?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Because she thinks like me, that's why.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: She's faithful as a rock, don't you know. In my worst moments I can think of her-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I think again, that I'm-I'm right.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Look, it's a nice day. What are we arguing for?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Nobody in my house better ever dare-dare to challenge her faith. Maybe strangers, but not his father, not his brother.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Calm yourself.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Because he's not coming back. Then what do I got to live for? I'll kill myself.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Calm yourself.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Don't, don't laugh at me, don't laugh at me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Look at it. Because why, when she came here and she slept in his room, the memorial broke into pieces. Look at it, look at it, Joe.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: All right. All right. Calm yourself.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You got to believe, believe with me because I can't stand all alone.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay. Just calm yourself.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, you've got to believe.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Believe, Joe. You above all people have got to believe.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why me, above all?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Huh?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why me above all?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You got to keep believing.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Look at you, you're shaking.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I can't help it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What have I got to hide?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Huh? What the hell's the matter with you, Kate?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Hey, what time is it?  This pokes around midnight right?  God this is great isn't it?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Look at the night we got.  I wouldn't trade this for anything.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know actually I wanted to go a little further up the coast and get away from all the lights and people but I was afraid you'd miss it.  How are you doing?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Fine.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Is that, is that, nah, is that just Paul?  I can't even tell.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: But if I can't tell, it probably isn't them isn't it?  Probably would be unmistakable wouldn't you think?  How are you doing?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, you know what I forgot?  I forgot my flashlight.  How could I be so stupid?  I should've brought my flashlight.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What flashlight?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know, the flashlight, the silver one?  There's only one isn't there?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's not your flashlight.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, whose is it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's ours.  Mine too.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, sure.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, you keep saying it's my flashlight like it's only your flashlight.  I mean, how do you think that makes me feel?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No.  Of course, our flashlight.  Yours and mine.  Me flashlight is su flashlight, naturally.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: How could we have not thought to bring it?  I hope the moon stays out.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Was it a full moon last year when they were running?  I can't remember.  Do you remember?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yes.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Are you cold?  Do you want my jacket?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We should've brought the blanket, our blanket.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: God.  Oh, you know what would be good right about now?  A six-pack.  A six-pack would be just the ticket.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm so stupid, I should've brought a six-pack.  God, I'm like a little kid.  It's amazing I get out of the house with my fly zipped up. Oh- [LAUGHTER]

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I wonder if they can hear us talk?  Or feel the vibrations in the sand when we move around?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Look, I'm cold.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Do you want my jacket?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's past eleven, let's go.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What?  Are you kidding me?  We just got here.  We miss it.  What's the point of coming down here if we just turn around and go home?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: There is no point in coming down here.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Right.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That's my point.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That's my point too...No.  No.  That's not my point.  My point is what's the point if we come down here if we just turn around and leave?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: So let's go.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I mean, don't you want to see it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Not particularly.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why not?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't know.  I just don't.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Honey, this is a natural phenomenon.  It only happens once a year.  I mean think about the people in Kansas, they would have to get hotel reservations and plane tickets to come and see this.  We're only forty minutes away.  This is too good to pass up.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Pass up what?  These fish swim up to shore, on the beach and then they flop around a little, they swim away and then they die.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well this is like the highlight, the one night of their lives and that flopping around, that's laying eggs or spawning or mating or whatever you call it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: But this is the big night for these guys.  Their last, life's last orgy.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What are you getting so excited about?  I mean, it's not like it's like the landing on the moon or something.  I mean, it's just fish, fish that nobody eats.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah they do.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Augie.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay.  But it's fish that do something that no other fish do.  Like the swallows in Capistrano or the Lemmings that throw themselves off the cliffs, there's magic here and some mystery and a little bit of unexplainable.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I mean, I can't see how you can not be interested.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm just not.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: For real?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yes.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't get it.  I mean the first time we came to see it, you said it was the best night of your life.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And last year when we came you ran out of the house so fast you stubbed your toe and you didn't even notice it until we got in the car.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You also could remember that I got sand in my panties, we got in an argument over nothing, you got a sore throat and we didn't even get to see the Grunions.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay.  We're in a good spot.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You didn't see them the first time either.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We just weren't in the good spot.  This is a much better spot.  You know, I have a good instincts for these things.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Look, is that...no is that just seaweed?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know, this is great isn't it?  You know, I wouldn't trade this for anything.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I mean, think about this, I know you're not interested but just think about this for a minute.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Somewhere out there, there's this huge silver mass of fish heading this way, they don't why, we don't know why, they just some little instinctual fire cracker went off in their bodies...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: ...like and they all just turned at once and formed a line as long as the California coast and started swimming this way.  They didn't, you know, they didn't make a decision, they didn't, you know, have boats or anything.  No one sent them an invitation or a map, they just started swimming as if that's the only thing that matters.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's single mindedness with no mind.  It's urgency that's pure urge and they don't, they don't ask it a question, they don't give it a name, they just swim.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: They just start swimming to this place right here where we stand for massive celebration of sex and death.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, I'm giving myself goose bumps.  Look, all my hairs are standing up.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That's the wind.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: [BREATHING] So what do you think?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: About what?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: About what I just said?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's ridiculous.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It certainly is not.  It's

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What's he going to say?  Maybe we ought to talk to him before he sees it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: He saw it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What do you mean. He couldn't have seen it. I was the first one up, he was still in bed.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: He was out there when it happened.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: When?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: About four in the morning.  I heard a crack and I looked out and he was standing right there when it happened.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well what was he doing out at four in the morning?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know. But after it cracked he ran back into the house and he cried in the kitchen.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Did you talk to him?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No.  I figured the best thing to do was leave him alone.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: He cried hard?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I could hear it right through the floor.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: God, what was he doing out there anyway?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Starting to dream about him again.  He's walking around at night again.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I guess he is.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: He's getting just like he did after he died, you know?  What, what, what's the meaning of this?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know.  But I know one thing mom, we made a terrible mistake with dad.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Being dishonest with him.  That kind of thing always pays off and now it's paying off.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What do you mean dishonest?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know that Larry's not coming back and I know that too.  Why we both go on letting him think that we both believe with him.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What are you going to do?  You want to argue with him?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No I don't want to argue with him but, it's time that he realizes that nobody believes Larry's coming back anymore.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why shouldn't he walk around and dream at him at night.  Walk around.  Why shouldn't he walk around?  Why shouldn't he dream of him, walk around at night waiting for him?  Do we contradict him?  Do we say flat out that we don't have anymore hope?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That we haven't had any hope for years now?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You can't say that to him.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We got to say it to him.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: How are you going to prove it?  Can you prove it?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Larry's been gone for three years.  For god sakes no one comes back after three years.  It's insane.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: To you maybe, to me, but not to your father.  I mean,

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: he still thinks he's alive still.  I mean you could talk yourself blue in the face and there's no body and there's no grave so where are you?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Listen mom, just, sit down.  I want to talk to you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.  It's his god damned newspapers is what it is.  Now every month there's a new boy comes home and Larry's going to be the next one.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Alright. Alright. Alright just listen.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know why I asked Annie here, right?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Why?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well I have an idea but I don't know.  What's the story?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I want to ask her to marry me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well that's your business Chris.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know it's not just my business.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well what do you want me to do?  I mean, you're old enough to know your own mind.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay.  So then it's alright.  I'll go ahead with it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, I mean, you got to make sure your dad's not going--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh see then it's just not my business. God you infuriate me sometimes.  Isn't my business too if dad throws a fit?  Huh?  God you have such a talent for ignoring things.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well I'm just saying--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You know I ignore what I got to ignore.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: She's not...she's Larry's girl.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: She's not Larry's girl.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: From your father's point of view he is still alive and if you try and take her that's just not fair.  You can't do that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know why it is but every time I reach out for something I want I have to pull back

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And-And-And if you go on from there if you know already to go on from there, then you can.  But I'm telling you something that I don't know where to go.  You got it?  I mean, do you?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Because other people will suffer.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: My whole entire, bloody life time and time again.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You're a considerate fellow.  There is nothing wrong in that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well to hell with that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Did you ask Annie yet?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I wanted to get this settled first.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And what if she doesn't marry you huh?  What if she feels the same way your father does?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Then I guess that's the end of it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: But from her letters I think she's forgotten him.  I'll find out.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And then we'll thrash it out with dad right?  Mom, don't avoid me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Look, you never had seen many, many women.  You know?  I mean...

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well so what?  I'm just not fast with women.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well I just don't see why it has to be Annie.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Because it is.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well that's a good answer but, it doesn't answer anything.  You haven't seen her since you left to go to the war and it's been five years.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's just...that's just the way it is.  That's how I feel.  You know these years when I think of someone I want to marry I think of Annie.  What do you want a diagram?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No I don't want a diagram.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: He thinks he's coming back. And you go off and marry that girl and you're just pronouncing him dead and what's going to happen to him?  I don't know.  Do you?  I mean, I don't know.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Alright then.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Look, just give it some thought okay?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I've given it three years of thought and I thought that if I waited then dad would forget about Larry and then we could have a regular wedding and everything happy.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: But if I can't have that here I'll get out.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What the hell is this?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'll get out.  I'll marry her somewhere else.  Maybe New York.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Are you crazy?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I've been a good son too long.  A good sucker and I'm through with it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You're just going to leave the business?  You have a business here.  You can't do that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: The business doesn't inspire me.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, you have to be inspired.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes.  I like it an hour out of the day.  If I have to grub for money all day long at least at evening I want it beautiful.  I want a family.  I want a wife.  I want some kids.  I want to build something I can give myself to.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Now Annie is in the middle of all that.  Where do I find it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Tell me something.  You can leave this business?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes.  On this I would.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You can't talk like that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Then help me stay here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Alright but you can't talk like that you hear?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I mean what the hell have we worked for then?  I mean, it's all for you Chris.  The whole shooting match is for you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know.  Just you help me stay here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Alright but you don't talk like that you hear?  You don't.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I am thinking like that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't understand you do I?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No you don't.  I'm a pretty tough guy.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah.  I can see that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, man, I just -- I don't know what to do.  I don't know what to do.  It's like every job, you know, I go to; every job I apply to,

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: it's just like nobody- nobody wants to hire me. It's been years, I mean, do you understand, years?  Like, I'm -- you know what I mean, it's like I've been collecting unemployment for so long now, it's just like I just -- I can't take it.  I don't know what to do.  I mean, I'm just like losing my mind.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well there has to be something you haven't tried.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I-I'm not kidding.  I've tried everything.  Like I've gone to every business and local, you know,

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: local business in- in the area and I can't- I can't get anything.  Like, nobody -

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What about like a temp agency?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Have you gone, like, signed up with a temp agency?  Maybe they can help.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: there's just like no jobs available.  I mean, it's just like, God.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah, I tried that.  And there was like, yeah, like I did like one thing once.  But, like, that's not -- it doesn't last very long.  And it's not enough to live on.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Right, but you have -- I mean, you have to keep on them.  You have to keep calling and reminding them that you're still looking and

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I mean, you have to be really aggressive about it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah, I do.  I do.  You don't understand.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I- You don't understand. I don't have a job.  All- My job is to look for a job.  I don't do anything else.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: But, like, it's been years now and I just can't seem to get anything that really fits.  It's just it -- I -- it drives me absolutely insane.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well, I mean, if it's that bad, maybe you're gonna have to take something that doesn't really fit, you know.  Like maybe you'll have to do something else for a while.  Find a new field, new skill.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, no, no, no, no.  I can't- I can't do that.  I can't, I- because if I'm not- if I'm not- if I'm not doing something that I love, then I can't -- I can't- I mean it's- what's the point?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well then you're choosing to be unemployed, really.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm not choosing. I'm not-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: If you're not willing to try and work with it and find something and, you know, I mean, there are things you could do.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, but I'm try- but like all the things that I-it's like I apply to all these places and none of them

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: -- I mean, I don't understand.  It's like -- I mean, I feel like I'm qualified enough.  I just don't understand.  Like, I mean, it's just like a matter of circumstance, but it's been three years, you know, three years.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well maybe, you know, your luck it is just down and the market for your particular field is down and maybe you just need to look into doing something else for a while.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: This is stupid.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I mean, I'm not saying that you should, you know--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You know what, this is your fault.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Excuse me?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's your fault 'cause -cause you always told me to- to do this and I did that instead.  And I didn't take your advice and - and- but you sort of were like were telling--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's my fault 'cause you didn't do what I told you to?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah, exactly.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well that sounds like your fault.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You didn't do what I told you to do.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That's 'cause you always tell me to do the wrong thing.  And I thought this time it was -- I was gonna be right by going with the opposite thing. So it's your fault because

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: -because you were always wrong and-and-and this time you were right. And-and I didn't -- yeah, that's why.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That's amazing logic that you managed to turn that around and make it my fault.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, I mean, it makes sense, doesn't it, hmm?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I think maybe you can't get employed because you aren't willing to take responsibility for your own actions.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That's not true.  I take responsibility for my own actions.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Really?  Whose fault is it you don't have a job?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yours.  I don't--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: [LAUGHTER]

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You see what you just did there, though?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I had- No, I don't.  I'm sorry.  I just totally screwed this one up.  You can stop it I guess.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So you're leaving tomorrow.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah.  They just called.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: This is really-this is unfair.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I know.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't see [BREATHING]

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I don't know what to say.  I don't want to go but I don't have a lot of choice.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I mean we both knew that this was going to happen.  It's just that I feel that, you know, I don't want Susie growing up without a mother.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And, uh, I'm afraid that if you, you know, when you leave, you won't come back.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I'm going to come back.  I need you to believe that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You don't know that.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I need you to believe that too.  How am I supposed to believe everything's going to be okay if you don't?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'll believe it, but- I'll believe it but it- I don't know that that's going to happen.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well you have to have faith because I don't have a choice and I have to go.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You do have a choice.  You don't have to go.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Do you think I want to leave you?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You have a choice.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I have to do this.  I don't want to leave.  Do you think I want to miss seeing her grow up?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know.  It's just you don't have to do this for a living you know.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You're a smart person.  There are other things you can do.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Look we both knew what this meant when I signed on

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And now- and now it's really shitty timing but now I have to go.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I mean I'm the one who has to leave here.  I'm the one who has to leave the two of you.  At least you get to be together.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's just not going to work out without you here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What's that supposed to mean?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I mean we can't-we're not a complete family without you here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well I'll come back.  What is that supposed to mean?  You're not willing to wait for me to come back?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Of course I'm going to wait.  I just- I just don't like the idea of this happening because this isn't the last time this is going to happen. You're going to go on more tours and stuff.  I just- I can't-

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I can't deal with this emotionally.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What do you want me to do?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I want you to leave.  I want you to leave the service.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well I can't very well do it today.  I still have to leave tomorrow.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You can do it today.  You don't have to do anything.  You don't have to do anything you don't want to do.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You're not making this any easier for me, you know.  I'm the one who has to go and you're really not helping.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Look I'm just telling you that you don't have to go.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I do have to go. And I need to know that you're here waiting for me and that you believe that I'm coming back.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That's all I'm saying... No you don't.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Thanks that helps.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's just really unfair.  This is- this is bullshit.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I feel much better now.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You're acting like, you know, you're the one who's going all through, you know, all this shit and it's really- it's really not.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I know I'm leaving you here with all the responsibility but at least you get to be with her.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah.  Of course I do because I didn't enlist in this stupid thing.  Why don't you just get out now and then-

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I will but I can't right now.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes- You don't have to go.  What are they going to do?  Huh?  Put a gun to your head?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You know- you know how this works.  I have to go.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Then go.  We'll be here when you get back.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: That's how you want to leave it?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know how else to leave it.  What, do you want me to lie to you?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You want me tell you that I'm okay with it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I want you to be okay with it as much as you can be.  I mean it's not a great situation but we don't have an option here.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well I can't be okay with it the same way you can't not go.  It just doesn't work that way.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Fine.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Why did he invite her here?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh, God, line.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Why does that bother you?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why does- why, does that bother you?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: She's been in New York three and a half years.  Why, all of a sudden--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, maybe- maybe he just wanted to see her.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Nobody comes seven hundred miles just to see.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What do you mean?  He grew up next door to the girl all his life.  Why shouldn't he want to -- why shouldn't he want to see her again?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Don't look at me like that.  He didn't tell me anymore than he told you.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: He's not going to marry her.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: How do you know he's even thinking about it?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's got that about it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well so what?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: What's going on here, Joe?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Line.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Now listen, kid. Now, listen.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Oh.  Now listen, kid.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: She's not his girl, Joe.  She knows she's not.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You can't read her mind.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Then why is she still single?  New York is full of men.  Why hasn't she married?  Probably a hundred people told her she's foolish, but she's waited.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: How do you know why she waited?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Because she knows what I know, that's why.  She's faithful as a rock.  In my worst moments, I think of her waiting and I know, again, that I'm right.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Look, it's a nice day.  What are we arguing for?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Nobody in this house dares take her faith away, Joe.  Strangers might, but not his father, not his brother.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What do you want me to do? What do you want?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I want you to act like he's coming back, both of you.  Don't think I haven't noticed you since he invited her here.  I won't stand for any nonsense.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: But, Kate--

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Because if he's not coming back, I'll kill myself.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Laugh.  Laugh at me.  But why did that happen the very night that she came here?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: She goes to sleep in his bed and his memorial breaks in pieces.  Look.  Look at it.  Joe--

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Calm yourself.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Believe with me, Joe.  I can't stand all alone

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Calm yourself.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Only last week, a man turned up in Detroit missing longer than Larry.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Alright, alright.  Calm yourself.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You, above all, have got to believe.  You.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why me above all?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Just don't stop believing.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What does that mean, me above all?  Look at you.  You're shaking.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I can't help it.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What have I got to hide?  What the hell is the matter with you, Kate?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well, so what do you think?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: About what?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What I said.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's ridiculous.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It certainly is not.  It's slightly exaggerated scientific fact.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: It's PR.  Somebody sold you a bill of goods that this wonderful event is going to take place on the beach.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm not the only one.  Look at these people.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well sure everybody's told the same story.  It keeps us all coming back for more.  It keeps us all excited, keeps us thinking that life is going to start any minute now if we can just find the right spot and get in on the action.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Are we talking about the same thing?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well I'm sorry but it's still just fish to me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Carla, can I ask you something?  Don't take this the wrong way but are you having your period?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Goddamn it Augie don't ask me that.  You always ask me that.  I hate it when you ask me that.  It's insulting.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well then what's bugging you?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: We just have different ideas about what this evening is supposed to look like.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: There's nothing to it.  We come down here.  The grunions arrive.  They do their little fish business.  We go oh, ah look at the fish.  They go home.  We go home.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: For heaven's sake, this is not about fish.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why not?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: We totally skipped. Right.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: There's nothing to it.  We come down here.  The grunions arrive.  They do the little fish business.  We go oh, ah look at the fish.  They go home.  We go home.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: For heaven's sake, grow up we are not going to see the Grunions.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Why not?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: We never do.  Do we have we ever?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We've missed them twice that's not ever.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Twice is every time we've tried that's ever.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: We'll see them this year.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No, we won't.  It's pointless.  It's like waiting up to see Santa Clause.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: God I feel as though my entire life is going to be spent standing on the beach with my eyes wide open and my hands clasped expectantly waiting for the fish to show up,

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: and the fish won't show up.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I thought you wanted to see it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: You don't understand anything I'm saying.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, of course not.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I did want to see it.  I always do.  I keep thinking that this time will be the time but it never is.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's just a fish.  Nothing to get traumatized over.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: For heaven's sake, this is not about fish.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I've been trying to work this backwards but I can't seem to pinpoint the moment when we took a turn for the worse.  You were fine during the phone call from Marge.  Dinner was okay.  Doing the dishes was no problem.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Let's see I took a shower.  You watched the news.  You said the Grunions are running tonight. I said great let's go.  I feel lucky tonight.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay.  Uh, so I'm putting on my jacket, putting out the animals.  We're getting the car out of the garage.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Do you remember the first time we came to see it?  It was about four years ago right after we got married.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: We thought I was pregnant and we had a bottle of champagne but no glasses.  You asked me to dance.  So we took off our shoes

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: and you popped the cork and while we were dancing, you said the softest most intimate things to me

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: right into my ear so that I could hear them as much as- so that I could feel them as much as hear them.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: And I remember thinking this is it.  At last, at last I'm as happy as I'm supposed to be.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Wait a minute.  I've got it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Dancing barefoot in the sand, drinking champagne from the bottle.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It was in the car right.  Driving past the Knickerbocker Liquor Locker, you said let's get some champagne and I said times a wasting or something like that.  Right?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: That's it, right?  You want this to be like the other time, right.  That's it.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I would rather not remember some things.  I would rather not hope for some things.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Okay.  Right.  I got it.  Sure.  Of course.  Listen you want to dance?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: You want me to get some champagne?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Take off our shoes?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.  No.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well what?  Want me to breath in your ear?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Want to get married again?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: What?  What do you want a divorce?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: A vacation?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: A new carpet, a poodle, a backrub, ice cream, a suicide pact.  What?  What?  Carla what the hell do you want?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I want something to turn out the way it's supposed to.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well welcome to the human race.  You think this is what I had in mind.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Do you think that when I proposed, I had this great fantasy going that four years down the line we'd come to the beach and yell at each other over fish.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Do you think that I knew that there'd be times when you'd look at me like I'm a used Kleenex and times I would look at you and think holy hell when's the next flight to Alaska.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, no I'm just like you.  I thought it was going to be all peaches and roses and sand in our hair and wind in our

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Sand in our toes and wind in our hair and the fish will always come and the bills will always pay themselves and ha, ha baby the jokes on us.  Because you know what you get,

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: you know what you get Carla, this.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: This what, what is this?  This isn't even anything.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yes it is.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, right, sure this is standing on the beach.  This is waiting.  This is fighting.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Right.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: But this isn't anything like I thought anything would be like.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, I know me either.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: This is just this.  I mean it includes a lot in everything but it's just not, you know, something else.  Do you have any idea what I'm trying to say?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I'm doing the best I can.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I know you are, Augie.  Really I do.  I know you wanted this to be special and nice and it's the full moon and the sand and all but I just couldn't help thinking about being somewhere else.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Maybe if you were with somebody else too.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: I didn't say that.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: No, I know but still.  I know I don't make you happy.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: For heaven's sake, whatever I'm doing I'd rather be doing it with you.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Yeah?

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Well don't be ridiculous.  Don't you know that?  You're the one who probably wishes you were with somebody else

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: somebody who knew how to enjoy herself and didn't take everything so hard.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Actually now that you mention it, no I don't.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Okay.  Fine.  So we're in the wrong spot but we're with the right person.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't know.  It seemed like a good spot to me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I mean look at the view you've got of the moon from here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Yeah, I noticed that.  Looks pretty on the water doesn't it, big old white moon.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Well look at what we got here.

dialogue.speaker: F
dialogue.text: Oh, Augie you brought refreshments.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's not champagne.

dialogue.speaker: F

dialogue.text: Oh, Chris I've been ready for a long time.

dialogue.text: Not like that you're not.

dialogue.speaker: F

dialogue.text: No, nothing like that.

dialogue.text: You have to tell me.

dialogue.text: Yeah, I suppose I have been.  But it's going for me.

dialogue.text: You have to tell me.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I don't I don't know where to start.

dialogue.text: It wouldn't work like this.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It's so mixed up with so many other things.

dialogue.text: You remember when I was overseas, I was in command of a company?

dialogue.text: Yeah, sure.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I lost them.

dialogue.text: How many?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Just about all.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It- It takes time to toss something like that off,I mean, because they weren't just men.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: For instance, there was this time, and it had been raining for several days, and this kid came up to me and he gave me his last pair of dry socks, just put them in my pocket.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I know it's it's just a little thing but that's just the kind of guys I had.  They didn't die.  They killed themselves for each other.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I mean that exactly, anymore selfish -- just a little bit more selfish and they would have been here today. And it gave me an idea as I was watching them all go down.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: Everything was being destroyed see, but I felt like something new was being created at the same time.  Like it kind of -- responsibility.  You know, man to man.  Do you understand what I'm saying?

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: And and to see that again, to to bring that back on the earth again, like- like a monument that that would stand behind these men and and and it would make a difference to them.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It was and then I went home.  And it was incredible.  It didn't have any meaning there.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I mean, the whole thing was like some kind of bus accident to them.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: So I went back to work for my dad and that whole rat race again.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: I felt what you said, ashamed somehow because nobody had changed at all.

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: It seemed to make suckers out of so many guys.  And I-I felt wrong to be alive; to to open that bank book, to to drive that car, the new car, and look at that new refrigerator. I mean,

dialogue.speaker: M
dialogue.text: you can take those things out of the war, but if you're gonna drive that car you've got to know that that came from the love a man can have from a man. And you've got to be a little bit better because of that.  Because if you're not, then it's all just loot and there's blood on it and I didn't want any of it.
